entry.title: Assessment 1C - Animation in Blender
entry.content:
This is where you will learn about animation in Blender with your 1B PokeBall and stand.

Objective

Your objective is to animate your Assessment 1B PokeBall! You will be required to produce two animations:

Turntable


Bounce, Roll and Open


You may go an extra step and apply two principles of animation to one of the above!.

Step 1 - Setting up the Blender file

Video

Walkthrough written steps

Click here to see the steps.


1. Locate your A1B Blender File.
`
2. Duplicate this file (copy + paste) and rename it to DECO2018_A1C_YourUnikey.

3. Open this new Blender file.


Step 2 - Introducing the Animation workspace

Video

Walkthrough written steps

Click here to see the steps.


Congratulations! You have made it past the modelling workspace in Blender! üòÉ

  1. If you previously had face orientation on, turn this off.

  2. Press the Animation tab in the workspaces ribbon.

    You will notice that quite a bit has changed. Let‚Äôs break down the new workspace.

  3. We now see there are two viewports instead of one viewport. The viewport on the left is where you would preview your animation and the viewport on the right is where you would work on your animation.

  4. Below the viewports is a timeline. We will be in this area the most as it is where we can create our animations! If you have used a software like Adobe Animate or Adobe After Effects, it is quite similar in its workflow. It consists of:

  • The playhead denoted by the blue vertical bar. This is like the handle you see in a video player on platforms like YouTube.
  • The sheet which is the area in the centre. This is where your keyframes will be.
  • The player controls at the bottom-centre. This is a series of buttons to play, pause, rewind, record and jump to certain points, in the animation.


Step 3 - Introducing the Camera

Video

Walkthrough written steps

Click here to see the steps.


  1. We have previously stated to not worry about the Camera, well now its time to focus on the Camera in Blender! The camera is a second pair of eyes, the first pair of eyes is the viewport which is what we as the user see in Blender. The camera acts as an internal camera that can be set up for rendering and animations.

    In the left viewport, click on the Hamburger menu near the top, then go to View -> Viewpoint -> Camera. You will notice this rectangular box, this is what the Camera is currently seeing.

  2. Try moving the camera around in the right viewport, you will notice that it is moving as well in the left viewport.

    Our objective for the first animation, the turntable, is to position the camera to have it slightly above the Pokeball + stand as we want the top shell to move up.

    You will notice that is quite difficult to do so, with just manually adjusting the camera in the right viewport.

  3. In the left viewport, press N on your keyboard or go to View -> Sidebar to open the Sidebar.

  4. Press the view tab in the sidebar.

  5. Under the View Lock section, check the Camera to View checkbox. What this will do is instead of adjusting the viewport when you are using your mouse to move around, it will adjust the camera‚Äôs view.

  6. Still in the left viewport, try to move around with just your mouse. You will now notice that you are updating the camera‚Äôs position and rotation as well! Much easier üòÉ

  7. There is one issue! You will notice that as we zoom out, the Pokeball begins to clip. We need to update the clipping start and end, as the camera has different values for clipping compared to the viewport‚Äôs.

  8. With the Camera Selected, go to the Object Data Properties tab. It is denoted by the camera icon.

  9. Change Clip Start to 0.01mm and Clip End to 1000mm.


Step 4 - Turntable animation

Video

Walkthrough written steps

Click here to see the steps.


Now we are going to create our first animation! The turntable animation.

  1. Adjust the camera‚Äôs view to something as shown below, with space at the top and the stand slightly cut-off.

  2. Select the Top_Shell and move the playhead to frame 1.

  3. In the Object Properties tab, press the circular dot near the Location Z value.

    This will create a keyframe in the timeline.

  4. You will notice that if you de-select the Top_Shell, its keyframes disappear from the timeline. To still show these keyframes, you will need to toggle off the selected keyframes mode found on the top-right side of the timeline.

    When nothing is selected and selected keyframes mode is on.

    When nothing is selected and selected keyframes mode is off.

  5. We now want to move the Top_Shell up, this will create the explosion. Ensure that the Top_Shell is selected. Now press the record button located at the bottom of the timeline.

  6. Move the playhead to frame 50.

  7. Move the Top_Shell up on the Z-axis, to where it touches the top edge of the rectangle in the left viewport.

  8. You will now notice that Blender has automatically created the keyframe for us! But it has also annoyingly created a keyframe for every single other property üôÉ, but that‚Äôs okay because they are the same and have not changed.

    You can now turn off record mode.

  9. Move the playhead to frame 1 and play the animation! You can do this by either pressing Spacebar on your keyboard or pressing the right arrow at the bottom of the timeline.

    Great work! You have created your first animation in Blender!

  10. We can clean up the timeline by removing the redundant keyframes, box select everything but the Z Location keyframe.

    Right-click and press Delete keyframes.

  11. Move the playhead to frame 100 and select the keyframe at frame 50.

  12. Right-click and press Duplicate, this will automatically grab the duplicated keyframe for you to move to a new location.

    Move the duplicated keyframe to frame 100 and left-click to confirm.

    This will hold the lifted position of the lid for 50 frames.

    You can re-adjust this length by selecting the duplicated keyframe and pressing G to move it to a new location, left-click to confirm.

  13. Move the playhead to frame 130 and select the keyframe at frame 1.

    Just like the previous step, duplicate the keyframe and move it to frame 130.

    You can move the keyframes and adjust the timings however you like!

  14. In the top-left of the timeline area, press the Editor Type and select Graph Editor.

    You will notice that there is nothing but a single line!

  15. Zoom out and pan upwards (the controls are exactly like moving the viewport), you will see your keyframes!

  16. The graph editor allows us to adjust the easing of each keyframe, while still being able to move the keyframes. It works exactly like a spline curve!

  17. The transition between two keyframes can be adjusted by changing the Handle Type. Select a keyframe, right-click -> Handle Type.

    • Free - gives you control over both control nodes independently, i.e. moving one won‚Äôt affect the other.
    • Aligned - the standard control, i.e. a bezier curve between the two control nodes.
    • Vector - the opposite of Aligned, a linear curve between the two control nodes.

  18. The type of easing between at least two keyframes can be changed by interpolation. Select two keyframes and right-click -> Interpolation Mode -> Choose an interpolation and preview to get a different result. Experiment with these and choose the one that feels best to you. Do this for both sides of the animation (opening the lid and closing the lid).

  19. Rename the animation by pressing the arrow icon near Top_Shell in the scene hierarchy, then pressing the arrow icon near Animation. Click on the animation itself, in this case it is called Top_ShellAction.001 and rename it to ‚ÄúExplode‚Äù.

  20. We now want to rotate the camera around the exploding Pokeball model. Go to Add -> Empty -> Plain Axes (make sure your 3D cursor is at world origin).

    Rename this to Camera_Rotator.

  21. With the Camera_Rotator selected, go into its Object Properties and press the circle near the Rotation Z value.

  22. Press the record button and move the playhead to the end keyframe, (frame 250). A quick way to do this is by pressing the right arrow with a bar icon at the bottom-centre.

  23. Change the Rotation Z value to 360.

    Play the animation and you will see the axes spin seamlessly. Press the record button to stop recording.

  24. Select the Camera_Rotator, then select the Camera. It is important to select these in this order. A way to know that you have selected these correctly is by the Camera being highlighted in a darker shade of orange and blue, compared to the Camera_Rotator.

  25. Right-click -> Parent -> Object. This will parent the Camera to the Camera_Rotator. Meaning that the Camera will inherit the Camera_Rotator‚Äôs animation!

    Play the animation and you will see the camera spin seamlessly. You will notice that something is a bit weird, the camera slows down towards the end and at the beginning.

  26. Switch to Graph Editor and select both keyframes (you can do this by either box selecting, or pressing A on your keyboard)

  27. Right-click -> Interpolation Mode -> Linear. This will apply a constant rotation to the camera, with no easing mimicking a turntable.

  28. The last thing to do is move the Explode animation from the beginning of the animation to somewhere in the middle. Select the Top_Shell and go into the Dope Sheet.

  29. Select all the keyframes and move these towards the centre.

  30. Great! The turntable animation is finished, now we can render it. In the inspector toolbar, click on Output Properties.

    Ensure:

    • Resolution % is 100%.
    • Aspect X and Y are both 1.000.
    • Frame Start is 1, Frame End is 250 and Frame Step is 1.
    • Frame Rate is either 24 or 23.98.

  31. Press the file button below Output and specify a file name for the animation. Use the convention: DECO2018_A1C_yourUniKey_turntable. Then press Accept.

  32. Change the file format from PNG to FFmpeg Video.

  33. Press on the Encoding tab and change the Container from Matroska to MPEG-4.

  34. In the Encoding / Video section, change the Output Quality to High quality.

  35. In the left viewport, press the hamburger menu -> View -> Viewport Render Animation.

  36. The animation will now begin the render. You can see the progress by the cursor updating to the current frame number, it will be complete once it reaches the end frame which is 250. This will take some time depending on your computer‚Äôs performance.

  37. The animation will have saved into the location you specified earlier. Remove the 0001-0250 at the end of the file name, now play!

Great job, you have completed your first animation! Take a break before tackling the next animation.


Step 5 - NLA

Video

Walkthrough written steps

Click here to see the steps.


NLA stands for Nonlinear Animation. They are Blender‚Äôs way of composing multiple animations in one Blender scene without having to create a Blender file for each animation because that would be inefficient!

If you have ever used a video-editing software like Adobe Premiere Pro or Final Cut Pro, it works in a similar way. There is a track for each animation that is tied to an object. You can move these tracks around which adjusts when they get played, mute tracks that do not need to be edited or used and add new empty tracks for another animation applied to an object.

1. Change the Editor Type to Nonlinear Animation.

On the left are the tracks. They are grouped by the 3D Object. Within these groups are the animation tracks.
The orange bars represent the animation itself and its duration. You have the ability to move these around adjusting when they start / finish.</li>


2. Press the Push Down Action button that is located near the Camera_RotatorAction animation track.

You will see that under Camera_Rotator there is an NlaTrack which is the camera rotation animation and above it is an empty track called No Action - Blender is now able to edit the empty track for the Camera_Rotator object as it is the top-most one.

3. Repeat the above step, but for the Top_Shell - Explode animation track.

We can now begin working on our second animation!

Note

We will be changing a lot of the Pokeball‚Äôs structure and properties and the camera in the scene hierarchy. If you want to keep the current state of the Pokeball and camera, copy and paste these into a New Collection and hide it.


Step 6 - Bounce, Roll and Open animation

Video

Walkthrough written steps

Click here to see the steps.


  1. Hide your Stand object.

  2. Currently the PokeBall is separated into two parts - the Top_Shell and the Bottom_Shell. We want to move the PokeBall as a whole, rather than selecting them individually and moving them. Select the Top_Shell, in the right viewport, go to Object -> Snap -> Cursor to Active

  3. Go to Add -> Empty -> Sphere. We want to create a silhouette of the Pokeball, and the shape that resembles it the most is a Sphere. We have created the sphere in the centre of the PokeBall so when we increase its size, it increases from the centre and not from the bottom.

  4. Change the radius to 35.2mm.

  5. Rename the Empty sphere to PokeBall.

  6. Select the Top_Shell and Bottom_Shell first, then select the PokeBall. This order is important.

  7. Right-click -> Parent -> Object. This will parent the Top_Shell and Bottom_Shell to the PokeBall.

    Try to move the PokeBall object, you will see that the entire shell is moving in one piece!

  8. We need a ground for our PokeBall to land on. Go to Add -> Mesh -> Plane (Ensure the 3D cursor is at world origin).

    Set its size to 2000mm.

  9. In the left viewport, adjust the camera to something like this. Where the PokeBall is on an angle and there is more space on the left, than on the right.

  10. Go to Add -> Curve -> Bezier. We want to create a path for the PokeBall object to follow, this will make more sense as we progress.

    Set its radius to 50mm.

    Rename to PokeBall_Path

  11. Switch to Front view and hide everything but the PokeBall_Path.

  12. Search the Internet for a bouncing ball animation reference, ideally one where it does not show the ball. Note: a PokeBall does not adhere to a ‚Äòbouncy‚Äô ball in the Physics world, meaning Squash and Stretch won‚Äôt be applied here.

    Here‚Äôs one you can use.

  13. Add the downloaded reference image into your scene. Here‚Äôs a quick refresher:

    Create a new collection - call it References.

    Add -> Image -> Reference.

    Select the downloaded file and uncheck align to view.

    Rotate the reference image so that it is facing the front view, 90 on the X-axis.

    Increase its size to 670mm, centre the reference image (by resetting its position and ensuring the X Offset and Y Offset are -0.50) and enable transparency, reducing the opacity to 0.3.

    Rename the reference image to Ball_Path and lock it.

  14. Trace your Bezier Curve over the reference image. Remember it is E to extrude out a new point.

    • Change the Handle Type to Free for better control for each point.
    • Change the Handle Type to Aligned for each bottom point.

  15. Select the last point in the path and extrude a new point. Ensure that it is extruding only on the X-axis.

    Change its Handle Type to Vector so it becomes a straight line. This is the rolling line of the Ball.

  16. Hide the References collection.

  17. Select the PokeBall_Path, go to Object -> Set Origin -> Origin to Geometry

  18. Unhide the objects, and clean the path drawn (i.e. ensuring the Y values for each point are near / at 0, this is especially for the control points).

  19. Zero-out the position of the PokeBall_Path and move it slightly above the PokeBall itself. Adjust its scale to around 0.4 - 0.5.

  20. Select the PokeBall, go to the Object Constraints tab in the Inspector.

  21. Add Object Constraint -> Follow Path. We are going to have the PokeBall follow the path of the PokeBall_Path.

  22. Select the Target as the PokeBall Path, press Animate Path then check Fixed Position.

  23. Move the playhead to frame 0 (Or 1, no idea why I put it at 0 ü§¶‚Äç‚ôÇÔ∏è), then press the circle icon near Offset Factor.

    Note: If you are using an older version of Blender (<= 2.8), then you would need to right-click on the offset factor and press Insert Keyframe.

  24. Press record at the bottom of the timeline, move the playhead to the end frame 250 and change the Offset Factor value to 1.

    Don‚Äôt forget to stop recording! Play the animation.

  25. The animation is quite slow, we can speed this up by moving the keyframe at frame 250 closer, for a faster animation.

  26. You‚Äôll notice that the PokeBall is inside the plane, we will need to fix this. Find a bottom point as reference, and move the PokeBall_Path down until the PokeBall is sitting on the Plane.

  27. Continue to refine the path and animation until you are satisfied.

  28. We now want to have the PokeBall rotating as it bounces and rolls to its final position. Move to the first frame and adjust the Rotation Y value of the PokeBall to -121, then press the circle icon to create the keyframe.

  29. Go into record mode, move the playhead to when the PokeBall is no longer bouncing (mine is at frame 103, yours may be different) and adjust the Rotation Y value to 229.

    Great! We now have the PokeBall bouncing and rolling, now all that is left is to open the lid.

  30. Move the playhead to the last keyframe (where the Pokeball stops all together), and adjust the Rotation Y value to 360, then turn off record mode.

  31. Move the playhead 10 frames after the Pokeball has stopped rolling and is at rest.

  32. We want to rotate the Top_Shell to show the Pokeball lid opening, however if we try to rotate it it‚Äôs rotating around its centre point which intersects with the bottom shell. Select the Top_Shell, go to Object -> Snap -> Cursor to Active.

  33. Go to Add -> Empty -> Cube. We want to create a pivot point for the Top_Shell, so it rotates relative to that object and not to its centre.

  34. Turn on X-Ray Mode and reduce the radius of the Empty Cube to 1.6mm.

  35. Move the Empty Cube up so that it is touching the base of the Top_Shell.

    Then to the back of the Top_Shell.

  36. Rename the Empty Cube to Lid_Opener.

  37. We first want to make the Lid_Opener a child of the PokeBall. Select the Lid_Opener first, then select the PokeBall.

    Right-click -> Parent -> Object.

  38. Now the Top_Shell needs to be a child of the Lid_Opener. Select the Top_Shell first, then select the Lid_Opener.

    Right-click -> Parent -> Object. Ensure that you have ticked KEEP TRANSFORM.

  39. Select the Lid_Opener and press the icon near Rotation Y.

  40. Turn on record mode, move the playhead 20 frames after (For me this is frame 150), then adjust the Rotation Y value to -110. Turn off record mode.

  41. Refine the opening of the lid however you like!

  42. Rename the animations to Bounce_and_Roll and Lid_Open respectively.

  43. Press the file button below Output and specify a file name for the animation. Use the convention: DECO2018_A1C_yourUniKey_roll_bounce_open. Then press Accept.

  44. Change the file format from PNG to FFmpeg Video.

  45. Press on the Encoding tab and change the Container from Matroska to MPEG-4.

  46. In the Encoding / Video section, change the Output Quality to High quality.

  47. In the left viewport, press the hamburger menu -> View -> Viewport Render Animation.

Great job, you have completed your second required animation! Well done!

The next step is an optional animation, all the best.


Extra Step - 2 Principles of Animation

Using either animation, add two distinct principles of animation to it.

Submission

You will need to submit a .ZIP file, containing:

  • DECO2018_A1C_yourUnikey_turntable.mp4 (or .mov)
  • DECO2018_A1C_yourUnikey_bounce_roll_open.mp4 (or .mov)

Add a comment in the Canvas submission that states your two principles, for example:

  • Principle of Animation 1: Principle Name
  • Principle of Animation 2: Principle Name

That‚Äôs all for this week!
entry.summary: This is where you will learn about animation in Blender with your 1B PokeBall and stand.

entry.title: Week 7 Optional Prac
entry.content:
This is an optional practical to help you learn more about 3D modelling file types and creating a 3D-print ready object to be 3D printed!

File Types for 3D printing.

  • .blend - this is your Blender file. It is NOT what you import into a slicing program like Cura. This stores data about your Blender scene (models, modifiers, hierarchy etc) and what you edit to produce your model.
  • .stl - this is the file needed to be exported for each model from Blender. STL stands for Standard Triangle language, it describes the surface geometry of a 3D object without any representation of colour, materials, animations or textures. This format has two variants - ASCII and Binary. Binary is the most common and what we will be exporting in as they are more compact. Slicing programs work best with STL files.

File types for other 3D modelling use cases.

Beyond 3D printing, there are many other applications of 3D modelling. Typically in video game development!

  • .obj - exports the model‚Äôs surface geometry along with its materials and textures. Use this if you only need the materials and textures and nothing else, good for high quality static renders.
  • .fbx - exports everything. This includes the scene‚Äôs information such as lights, cameras and animations applied to objects. You can optionally export selected objects which retrieves that model‚Äôs information only. This file is typically used in game engines such as Unity!

Objective

Your objective is to model this Jack-O-Lantern Pumpkin! Please note, you do not need to 3D print this from Cura, it is just an exercise. It consists of two parts:

  • The lid + stem.

  • The body with the face cut out.

  • Assembled.

Note the walkthrough will show a different pumpkin design!

Video

Walkthrough

Step 1 - Extending the number of Undos

From observations, we have discovered that Blender has a default limit of 50 undos. We can increase this to 256 undos by:

  1. Going to Edit -> Preferences
  2. Going to the System Tab.
  3. Changing the Undo Steps to 256 which is the limit.

Step 2 - Pumpkin Body

  1. Create a UV Sphere

  2. You can optionally check Face Orientation in the Viewport Overlays.

  3. Go to Top View

  4. Go into Edit Mode

  5. We want to select the edges that run down the sphere and are opposite of each other. We can do so by selecting Edges and while holding ALT, clicking an edge. This selects an edge loop.

  6. We want to select the edge loop that is opposite of this. To do this we need to add on to our current selection, we do this by holding SHIFT + ALT then selecting the edge.

  7. Repeat this until you get a pattern you desire, this is an example:

  8. Scale in the selected edges, but not so much they intersect each other.

  9. Switch to vertex mode and select the bottom vertex. We want to make this vertex on the same level as its outer ring vertices so it becomes flat for a better 3D print.

  10. With the bottom vertex selected go into the Front View. Move the vertex down until it is flush with the other vertices.

  11. For less support material to be created during the 3D print process, you can repeat the last two steps but for any other vertices that are not flush with its sibling vertices (Only the bottom ring is necessary).

  12. Select the top vertex.

  13. With the top vertex selected go into the Font View. Move the vertex up until it is flush with the other vertices. You can perform step 11 on this top‚Äôs vertex outer ring of vertices.

Step 3 - Pumpkin Lid

  1. Go into Top View and ensure faces are selected. Box select all the top faces.

  2. Extrude upwards and scale inwards.

  3. Complete the stem! It is up to you how you want to rotate and position it.

  4. Go into Front View, Edit Mode, Toggle X-Ray mode on and ensure faces are selected. Now box select the top of the pumpkin including the stem created.

  5. Separate the lid from the pumpkin by right clicking -> Separate -> Selection.

  6. Rename the separated objects now to ‚ÄúLid‚Äù and ‚ÄúPumpkin‚Äù respectively.

  7. Select the lid and move it upwards. We now need to create a cylinder to support the closing and opening of the lid as the lid on itself with the step can be weak and not hold in place. You can also scale down the lid slightly to make it a snug fit, ensuring that the scale is between 0.990 to 1

Step 4 - Pumpkin Lid Support

  1. Add a cylinder.

  2. Move the cylinder up to the lid, so that it is slightly intersecting it.

  3. Solidify the lid with a thickness of 1.8mm. NOT the cylinder.

  4. If the cylinder is too long, you can go into Edit mode with faces selected, select the bottom face and move it up. Additionally if you want a more loose fit, you can scale down the cylinder.

  5. Move the cylinder so that it is intersecting within the lid itself, X-Ray will help with this.

  6. Select both the lid and cylinder. Union them!

  7. Move the combined lid down and re-scale accordingly such that it is slightly larger than the pumpkin.

  8. Ensure the object is renamed to ‚ÄúLid‚Äù and hide it.

Step 5 - Carving the Pumpkin

  1. With the Pumpkin selected go into edit mode and ensure vertex mode is on, and go into Front View.

  2. We are going to be using a new tool in Edit mode - the knife tool. This lets us cut new topology in the model.

  3. Left click on a vertex point and you will see a yellow rectangle with a red line. Think of this as a pen tool.

  4. To complete an empty selection press Spacebar.

  5. Let‚Äôs cut out one of the eyes by making a triangular shape cut, then pressing spacebar to confirm the cut:

    The red points indicate new vertices that will be created upon confirming the cut. Note that Blender automatically added these as we connected the vertices together.

    You will also notice that a left-click cut is an opaque rectangular point and a cut that is a result of going beyond that vertex to the new selected cut point is a transparent circle.

  6. Repeat the same steps but for the right eye.

  7. Cut out the nose now, note that if you try to just connect the left corner to the right corner it won‚Äôt make the cut through the indented vertex point. In that case we need to select that point as well.

  8. Now cut out the mouth of the Pumpkin! Using the two techniques shown above.

  9. You will notice that the cut faces have been selected. We can now deselect the faces that we do not need to remove. Change to the select tool (W) Hold SHIFT and left click these faces.

  10. Now press Delete on your keyboard -> Faces. Tada!

    We have cut out the faces without even needing to do any Boolean differences.

  11. If you don‚Äôt like the shape of what has been cut, you can individually move these vertices in edit mode.

  12. Once you are happy with the carved face, solidify the pumpkin with a thickness at least 1.8mm.

  13. Reposition the lid back to the centre and adjust again if you want.

Step 6 - Exporting parts for 3D printing

  1. Select only the Lid. Go to File -> Export -> .STL.

  2. Name the file ‚Äúlid‚Äù, ensure Selection Only is ticked. Then press Export STL.

  3. Repeat the steps for the Pumpkin, ensuring its name is ‚Äúpumpkin‚Äù or ‚Äúbody‚Äù. Note that with Apply Modifiers checked, any modifier that hasn‚Äôt been applied yet will be applied in the export process.

Step 7 - Importing into Cura

From the 3D printing induction, you would have gone through the process of installing and setting up Cura.

  1. Double-click the exported Lid STL file and it will open in Cura. If you are on Mac, you will need to open Cura then drag and drop the Lid STL file.

  2. Drag and drop in the body STL file.

  3. You will now see both of your parts in Cura!

So you would need to accommodate for this as well when arranging your models. A method to arrange models nicely is to use the Arrange All Models feature in Cura. Simply right-click on the bed and press ‚ÄúArrange All Models‚Äù

This gap would be the absolute minimum between each model, too close and the brim of the two objects can intersect.

This gap would be the absolute minimum between each model, too further out and the print would take a longer time and the chance of stringing is greater. Stringing occurs when small strings of plastic are left behind. This is typically due to plastic oozing out of the nozzle while the extruder is moving to a new location. They are also quite annoying to remove.

This would be the recommended distance between the models, roughly ¬Ω of a square in Cura.

Don‚Äôt send these off to print, this was just an exercise to get you ready for when you 3D print your own devices!

Thanks for your time!
entry.summary: This is an optional practical to help you learn more about 3D modelling file types and creating a 3D-print ready object to be 3D printed!

entry.title: Week 11 Tutorial - (Assessment 1D) Materials, Textures, Lighting and Rendering in Blender

link.title: Week 11 Tutorial - (Assessment 1D) Materials, Textures, Lighting and Rendering in Blender

entry.content:
This is Week 11‚Äôs tutorial where you will learn about materials, textures, lighting and rendering in Blender with your 1B or 1C PokeBall and stand.

Objective

Your objective is to render your PokeBall + stand! You will be required to produce the following render of a Heavy Ball.

You may go an extra step and apply your own variation of the PokeBall and render it with its lid open (LIKE A1C), but not the standard red-white PokeBall..

FAQs

Can the Pokeball be any colour/pattern we wish? Or do we have to the follow the tutorial's colours?

You are required to produce the Heavy Ball as shown above with its colours. Then for the extra step, you can apply your own variation of the PokeBall, but not the standard red-white PokeBall.


Do we have to create the heavy ball first and then another variance for the extra step?

Yes.


Can we go straight into making another variant while following the steps?

No.


We submit the heavy ball and our variation in the zip file correct?

Yes.


By variation, does that mean making like an Ultra Ball, after making the Heavy Ball?

Yes.


My camera view / final render looks like its clipping the PokeBall + Stand.

If your render has some funny faces or the PokeBall is not completely shown. Select your Camera and go into the Object Data Properties, changing the clip start to 1mm and the clip end to 1000mm.

Also, make sure to delete any objects as a result of a Non-Destructive Boolean (COMBINED_DIF) and no Mask object, or delete any object that is hidden or nested. For example, these two underlined should be deleted.


My paint looks fuzzy / weird areas are being painted!

This is due to overlapping UV faces. There are two workarounds, the first is quicker, but the second is more accurate.

Method A - Island Margins

Select your Top_Shell and go into Edit Mode. Ensure Face Selection is on and select all of the faces. Then go to UV > Smart UV Project and adjust the Island Margin to 0.05.

.

Method B - Moving UV Faces

Go to the UV Editing workspace tab and select your Top_Shell, and switch to Edit Mode.

Highlight the faces that have extra paint applied, for example here

In the right viewport, select all the faces by pressing A and then in the left viewport, zoom into the faces where the overlapping is occurring.

Go into ‚ÄúIsland‚Äù selection and select the group that has the overlapping paint.

Move it to an empty space, such as here. Then repaint!


Step 1 - Setting up Blender File from 1C

NOTE - if you still have your A1B file, please copy and paste that and rename it from A1B to A1D and skip this step.

If you do not have access to your A1B file and only A1C (which is the animations), then please follow these steps.

Video

Walkthrough written steps

Click here to see the steps.


NOTE - if you still have your A1B file, please copy and paste that and rename it from A1B to A1D and skip this step.

If you do not have access to your A1B file and only A1C (which is the animations), then please follow these steps.

  1. Open your A1C file.

  2. Press the Animation tab in the workspaces ribbon, if it is not already selected.

  3. Turn off auto keyframe mode.

  4. Select the References collection in the scene collection.

  5. Right-click on it and press Delete Hierarchy. This will recursively delete the collection with its items inside.

  6. Reveal the Stand.

  7. Select the Plane and in the Scene Collection area, right-click and press Delete.

    Repeat this for the PokeBall_Path.

  8. Select the PokeBall and go to the Object Constraints tab.

  9. Press the X button located at the top-right of the Follow Path card, to remove it.

  10. Select the Camera which is nested inside the Camera_Rotator.

  11. Hover your cursor in the viewport area and right-click > Parent > Clear Parent. This will de-parent the Camera from the Camera_Rotator.

  12. Select the Camera_Rotator and in the Scene Collection area, right-click and press Delete.

  13. Select the Bottom_Shell which is nested inside the PokeBall.

  14. Hover your cursor in the viewport area and right-click > Parent > Clear Parent. This will de-parent the Bottom_Shell from the PokeBall.

  15. Select the Top_Shell which is nested inside the PokeBall > Lid_Opener.

  16. Hover your cursor in the viewport area and right-click > Parent > Clear Parent. This will de-parent the Top_Shell from the PokeBall.

  17. Select the Lid_Opener and in the Scene Collection area, right-click and press Delete.

    Repeat this for the PokeBall.

  18. Select the Top_Shell and go into the Object Properties tab in the inspector.

  19. Change the Location X value to 0 and change the Location Z value to where the Top_Shell is sitting above the Bottom_Shell.

  20. Switch to the Modelling workspace tab.

  21. Save the file by going to File > Save As‚Ä¶ and rename from A1C to A1D.


Step 2 - Material on Bottom Shell

Video

Walkthrough written steps

Click here to see the steps.


Let‚Äôs create our first Material on Blender for the Bottom Shell.

  1. Select the Bottom_Shell.

  2. Select the Material Properties tab which is denoted by the red checkered circle icon, in the inspector.

  3. Press the + New button to create a material.

  4. Rename the material by selecting the text box, and name it Light_Grey.

  5. Select the Preview text to open the preview pane. Here we can view our material applied on a selectable list of types of Meshes.

  6. Select the Surface text to open the surface pane. Here we can adjust parameters of the material to change its style.

  7. For now, we are only interested in changing the material‚Äôs base colour (Albedo). Select the rectangle near Base Color.

    Adjust the colour to a light grey.

  8. However, despite changing the colour. It is not showing in the viewport. This is because we are still in Solid view. Change to Material Preview, located at the top-right of the viewport.

    The white material that is on the Top_Shell and Stand is a default material that Blender applies for those objects that do not have any material applied.

  9. If we change the colour of the Light_Grey material again, it will update in the viewport as well.


Step 3 - Texture Painting on Top Shell

Video

Walkthrough written steps

Click here to see the steps.


Now let‚Äôs look at another way of creating a material / texture in Blender, through Texture Painting! It‚Äôs like Microsoft Paint, but for 3D.

  1. Go to Google Images and search for a reference image of a Heavy Ball PokeBall.

  2. Download the image and save it in the same location as your Blender file, naming it Heavy_Ball_Reference.

    Or you can download it here:

  3. Before doing any texture painting, we need to first unwrap the UVs of the Top_Shell. Select the Top_Shell and switch to Edit Mode. Ensure you have Face Selection on.

  4. Select all the faces by going to Select > All or pressing A on your keyboard.

  5. Unwrap the UVs by going to UV > Smart UV Project and press OK. Do not change any of the parameters.

  6. Switch to the Texture Paint workspace located at the top.

  7. On the left, is the unwrapped UVs for the Top_Shell.

    On the right, is the viewport with a coloured object which represents the object that had its UVs unwrapped.

  8. Switch the view from Solid to Material Preview.

  9. On the right, press the + button near No Textures, and select Base Color.

  10. Name the texture paint slot Heavy_Ball_Texture_Paint and press OK.

  11. By pressing left-click on the Top_Shell in the viewport, we can now paint on it. This is because we have the Draw mode selected in the Toolbar.

  12. Changing the mode to Soften in the Toolbar, allows us to smooth out sharp / jagged edges.

  13. Changing the mode to Smear in the Toolbar, allows us to spread the paint applied in a specific direction.

  14. Changing the mode to Clone in the Toolbar, allows us to paint an object based on a reference point colour. This is similar to Photoshop‚Äôs Stamp and Clone tool. To select a reference point, hold CTRL or CMD and left-click somewhere on the object, then you can paint anywhere else.

  15. Changing the mode to Fill in the Toolbar, does what you would expect. Fill in the entire object with a colour, with a single left-click.

  16. The radius (size) of the brush can be adjusted in the toolbar at the top. The change is denoted by the larger white circle surrounding the cursor, which represents the radius.

    Pressing F on your keyboard adjusts the radius of the brush, we move the cursor outwards (making it larger) or inwards (making it smaller).

  17. The strength of the brush can be adjusted in the toolbar the top. The lower the strength, the more transparent / less effective the brush is.

  18. In the left viewport, press the image dropdown at the top and select the Heavy_Ball_Texture_Paint. This will overlay our texture paint onto the UVs, allowing us to accurately see what has been painted - this updates in real-time as we paint as well.

  19. Press the editor type dropdown located at the top-right of the scene collection and select Image Editor. This will replace the Scene Collection with the Image Editor.

  20. In the Image Editor, go to Image > Open and open the downloaded Heavy_Ball_Reference file.

  21. In the Image Editor, go to View > [‚úî] Display Texture Paint UVs and uncheck it. This will hide the UV overlays, allowing us to see the reference image clearly.

  22. Select the Color Palette pane under Brush Settings and press the + New button, renaming it to Heavy_Ball_Palette.

  23. Select the colour picker above it by pressing on the white rectangle.

  24. Select the eyedropper and left-click on the dark blue section of the Heavy_Ball_Reference image.

  25. Press the + button underneath the Color Palette, this will create a swatch with the dark blue.

    Repeat the previous step and this step, but for the light blue circle in the reference image.

  26. Select Fill mode in the Toolbar, select the dark blue swatch and left-click anywhere on the Top_Shell in the viewport.

  27. Select Draw mode in the Toolbar and select the light blue swatch.

  28. Press Falloff to open the pane which adjusts the smoothness of the paint applied to the object.

  29. Press the Falloff type dropdown and change it to Constant.

  30. Change the brush‚Äôs radius to a size that resembles the smaller circle in the reference image (Mines at 93px).

  31. Press Symmetry to open the pane which allows you to mirror the brush‚Äôs paint based on a chosen set of axes.

  32. Select Y in the button group.

  33. Paint on the Top_Shell at a location that is similar to the small circle location in the reference image.

  34. Increase the brush radius and paint on the Top_Shell again for the larger circle.

  35. Select Soften mode in the Toolbar, and work your way around each circle on one side to smoothen the edges.

  36. The painting and smoothening of the circles appear on both sides of the Top_Shell.


Step 4 - Material on Lid

Video

Walkthrough written steps

Click here to see the steps.


Let‚Äôs look at how to have multiple materials applied to an object.

  1. Switch to the Modelling tab.

  2. Ensure you are in the Material Properties tab and rename the material to Heavy_Ball_Base.

  3. Press the + button near the list of materials to create a new material slot for this object.

  4. Go into Edit Mode and ensure you have Face selection on. Then make a box selection of a few faces on the lid.

  5. Go to Select > Select Linked > Linked.

    Select UVs in the Select Linked All window at the bottom-right.

    Select all the faces that make up the lid.

  6. Select the empty material in the Material Properties tab.

  7. Press the + New button underneath the material list to create a material for the empty material slot.

    Rename it to Button or Lid.

  8. With the faces still selected, press the Assign button.

  9. Change the base colour of the Button material to a light blue.


Step 5 - Texture on Rings

Video

Walkthrough written steps

Click here to see the steps.


Let‚Äôs look at another method of applying a material, through a texture map!

  1. Go to Google Images once again and search for a Dark Silk Texture.

    Note: The imagesize:256x256 is a way to search for images in Google Images by a specified width x height dimension.

  2. Save the image as Ring_Texture_Map in the same location as where your Blender file is.

    You can download the texture here:

  3. With the Top_Shell selected, create another material slot by pressing the + button near the list of materials.

  4. Go into Edit Mode, ensure Face selection is on and select all the faces that make up the ring.

  5. With the faces still selected, select the empty material slot and press the + New button underneath the list of materials.

  6. Press the Assign button to assign the plain material to the ring faces.

  7. Rename the material to Ring.

  8. Press the yellow dot that is to the right of the Base color text, and select Image Texture.

  9. Press the Open button underneath Image Texture and select the downloaded Ring_Texture_Map.jpg file and press Open Image.

  10. Go into Edit Mode and select the ring faces, a shortcut is to press the Select button which is next to the Assign button in the Material Properties tab for the Ring material.

  11. Switch the UV Editing workspace - here we can adjust the UVs themselves for the selected faces of an object.

  12. Select all of the UV vertices / faces. By either pressing A on your keyboard or making a box selection.

  13. Rotate the UVs by 90Àö.

  14. Repeat the previous steps, but for the Bottom_Shell ring.

    NOTE: Make sure to unwrap the UVs first.

    Also, instead of creating a new material for the ring faces, you can re-use the already made Ring material by pressing the dropdown and selecting the Ring material.


Step 6 - Material on Stand

Video

Walkthrough written steps

Click here to see the steps.


Let‚Äôs add a basic material to the stand, this should be relatively straight forward üòé.

  1. Select the Stand.

  2. Create a new material by pressing the + New button.

  3. Rename the material to Stand.

  4. Change the base colour to a very light blue.


Step 7 - Lighting

Video

Walkthrough written steps

Click here to see the steps.


Let‚Äôs now look into adding lighting to our scene.

  1. Switch the view from Material Preview to the furthest on the right, Rendered. You will notice that everything is quite dull, this is because the only light is within the PokeBall.

  2. Select the Light in your scene. In the inspector, go to the Object Data Properties which is shown as a green outline of a light bulb.

  3. Move the light, so that it is outside the PokeBall.

  4. In the Object Data Properties tab, change the Type from Point to Sun. It will update the lighting in the entire scene.

  5. Change the strength of the light to 5.

  6. Drag the yellow gizmo that is near the sun, to change the direction of the sunlight.

  7. For a more cartoon look, tick off Shadows in the Object Data Properties tab.

    Optionally, you can tick on Shadows and adjust the Bias, the lower the bias the more shadows appear and the higher the bias, the less shadows appear.

  8. Select the Top_Shell and go to Object > Snap > Cursor to Active.

  9. Add > Light > Spot to add a spot light in your scene.

  10. Move the Spot light out on the X-axis, then rotate it on the Y-axis by 90Àö.

  11. With the Spot light selected, in the Object Data Properties tab, change the Power to 0.03.

  12. Change the size of the Spot Shape to 38.2Àö.

  13. Reduce the Specular to 0, to not receive any light reflection.

  14. Change the Colour to a lighter colour than the Lid/Button‚Äôs colour.

  15. Rename the Spot light to Lid_Highlight and the Light (sun) to Sun.


Step 8 - Rendering

Video

Walkthrough written steps

Click here to see the steps.


The final step! Rendering the scene üì∫

  1. Set the cursor to world origin by going to Object > Snap > Cursor to World Origin.

  2. Add a Mesh > Plane with a size of 350mm.

  3. With the Plane selected, go into Edit Mode and press the Loop Cut tool.

  4. Hover your cursor until the yellow line is running horizontally through the Plane, Left-click and hold, moving it up towards the top of the plane and then release.

  5. Go into Face selection and select the cut face.

  6. Extrude the face upwards.

  7. Go into Edge selection and select the cut edge.

  8. Bevel the edge with a width of 21.5mm and increase the segments to 20.

  9. Scale the plane on the Y-axis to roughly 2.5.

  10. Move the plane downwards on the Z-axis until the stand is sitting on it, and rename the plane to Background_Plane.

  11. Create a material for the plane and give it a dark grey colour.

  12. Open the sidebar either by pressing the arrow or N on your keyboard, go to the View tab and check Camera To View in the Lock section.

  13. Set the viewport to the Camera by going to View > Viewpoint > Camera and adjust the view of the camera.

    Adjust the camera‚Äôs view.

  14. At the top, press the Show Overlays button to hide the gizmos, for a preview.

  15. To render the scene, go to Render > Render Image at the top main navigation bar. Note the rendering process takes time, depending on your Computer.

  16. In the Blender Render window, go to Image > Save.

  17. Press the dropdown near File Format and select JPEG, and name your file to DECO2018_A1D_yourUnikey_render.

  18. Change the quality to 100% and press Save As Image, ensuring that you have selected the same location as to where your Blender file is located.

  19. In the Inspector toolbar, select the Render Properties tab that is denoted by the white camera outline.

  20. Check Bloom and adjust the parameters as you wish, mainly the colour, threshold and radius for a cinematic-like effect.

  21. Some additional material properties that you can adjust include:

    The Metallic material property, adjusts the amount of shininess.

    The Specular material property, adjusts the amount of reflection.

    The Roughness material property, adjusts the amount of smoothness.

  22. To smooth out an object for rendering purposes, select the object, e.g. the Top_Shell.

  23. Go into Edit Mode and have Face Selection on, and select all faces.

  24. Go to Mesh > Normals > Smooth Vectors.

    Its now smooth! Note: the bump at the front can be photoshopped üòÖ.


Extra Step - Variation of PokeBall with (A1C) open lid

Create a variation of your PokeBall (Please not the standard design) and render it with its lid open (LIKE IN A1C).

Submission

You will need to submit a .ZIP file, containing:

  • DECO2018_A1D_yourUnikey_render.jpeg <‚Äî Heavy Ball
  • DECO2018_A1D_yourUnikey_extra_render.jpeg <‚Äî Your own design / another design that is not the standard red PokeBall

That‚Äôs all for this week!
entry.summary: This is Week 11‚Äôs tutorial where you will learn about materials, textures, lighting and rendering in Blender with your 1B or 1C PokeBall and stand.
